name: Powel Block 4
comment info: This graph shows the relationship between the passage of time and the percentage of Americans born abroad, with relation to two variables. The graph shows that we had a high percentage (10-15%) of foreign-born Americans between 1850 and 1910 (most of these immigrants were Canadian, Irish, and German). Then in 1921 Congress introduced quotas per country on immigration. This put a limit on the amount of people from each country that could be granted citizenship per year. This saw a plummet in all immigration until it was rolled back in 1965. After 1965, through to 2010, the percentage went back up to 10-15. The immigrants, however, were from different countries. The main countries on the part were Mexico and extraneous areas of Asia and Europe (as well as small amounts of Middle Easterners and Africans).

comment info:
Immigration: The Heart of America

In this graph, I notice that from 1921 to 1965 the percent of U.S. population that was born abroad rapidly decreased. According to the graph, this is because Congress created country-based immigration quotas. I also noticed that beginning in the 1970s, the U.S. population started to consist of people from Africa, the Middle East, and Mexico. 

From looking at this graph, I wonder why most of the immigrants from 1850 to 1921 were from Ireland and Germany. What was the reason for their immigration? This graph also makes me wonder why immigrants from Asia and ‘other’ areas came mostly in the 1970s and so on. Was there a specific reason for their lack of immigration to the U.S. before the 1970s? 

This graph represents the percentage of the U.S. population that was born abroad. It follows immigration to the U.S. starting in the 1850s and continuing until 2010. Each prominent country is represented by a color and it either declines or increases, depending on what was going on in their country at the time, or what rules/regulations the U.S. had passed regarding immigration. 

This graph relates to me because my father is a child of an immigrant. His mother lived in Italy, but decided to immigrate to America after World War II. This graph also relates to my community because most of the people around me have stemmed from immigrants. We all have some sort of story to share on how our family’s reached America and it bonds us as a community.

name: Emma AOSE
comment info:
I immediately noticed the decline of immigrants from the creation of the immigration quotas to the end of the quotas. Prior to 1965, most immigrants in the United States were from Ireland, Germany, as well as Canada. Then from 1965 and forward, there was a shift in demographics. There is a constant increase of immigrants from Asia and the Americas, especially Mexico. 

What factors caused this shift? And what caused the population of Irish immigrants to decline and not “bounce back” after the quota system rolled back? Perhaps the growing U.S. economy, education, safety and refuge from the Vietnam War, and new opportunities contributed to the surge of immigrants. 

These population changes affect my community in many ways. It increases population, diversity, economic output and growth. It also makes me wonder what the future holds for immigration rates.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
This graph encourages you to quantify immigration.  Should we say the “number of immigrants” or the “amount of immigrants"? 
 
Here’s the rule on using number or amount.  If you can count something (1, 2, 3, …), then use number.  If you can’t count it (grains of sand, happiness, …), then use amount.  

So, for the immigrants, is it the number of immigrants or the amount of immigrants?

name: KatieD AOSE
comment info: This graph demonstrates the change in immigration from the year 1850 to after 2010.  In the 1800s, there was a large amount of Irish and German immigrants and a small amount of Canadians.  In 1920, the US government implemented an immigration act that set quotas for how many immigrants could come from each country.  In the 60s, this quota was taken away and immigration began to rise again.  On the right side of the second line, the largest group is no longer Europe, but rather Mexico and Canada.  The main thing that stands out is the large decrease after the quota was put in place.  It was probably very difficult for people to come to America at this time.  I wonder what caused the shift in what people were immigrating.  I wonder if wars in Asia had anything to do with this increase in their immigration after the quota was dropped.  Immigration is relevant to the community because people from new places are constantly coming to America and it is important to be aware of the situation.  I would call this, "A Shift in Immigration Demographics"

name: Lisa
comment info: One thing I noticed was the significant decrease in immigrants in the population after congress created country-based immigration quotas. This makes me wonder how the government came up with these cap numbers. I imagine they would use country population sizes and percent of immigrants already in the US population to decide how many more immigrants they can accept from each country every year. However, I wonder if racism also factored into this decision. For example, we learned about the Chinese Exclusion Act which prohibited all immigration of Chinese workers for ten years. Perhaps this accounted for why the population of Asian immigrants is lower than immigrants from other continents. I also noticed that data about African immigrants doesn’t go all the way back to the 1850s and seems to start as late as the 1970s. This makes me wonder if data on African immigrant populations doesn’t exist before then. We learned about how African Americans' lineages can be very difficult to trace. This is largely a result of slavery since many slaves didn’t have birth and death certificates. This graph relates to me because both my parents are immigrants. My mom is from the Philippines and my dad is from England, and it’s interesting to see where they fit into the graph when they immigrated in the 1990s. They both came here for work and better opportunities which is the driving force for immigrants from many different countries. My catchy headline for this graph is “Immigration Nation”.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Chloe --

Thank you for the noticings.  Be careful of the use of the words number and amount.  This graph encourages you to quantify immigration.  Should we say the “number of immigrants” or the “amount of immigrants?”  

Here’s the rule on using number or amount.  If you can count something (1, 2, 3, …), then use number.  If you can’t count it (grains of sand, happiness, …), then use amount.  So, for the immigrants, is it the number of immigrants or the amount of immigrants? 

Also, is this graph even about number or about some other statistic?

name: Max R
location: Miami Country Day School in Miami, Fl
comment info: When looking at the model, I realize a few intersting things. Prior to the enactment of the 1921 country-based Immigration Quota, there was a larger proportion of Irish and Germans immigrants. This is sensible considering that during the latter half of the 19th century, the Irish potato famine resulted in a mass exodus of people seeking a better life in the US. Same with Germany, as economic hardship, religious persecution, and violent revolutions have caused millions to flee during a similar time period. Immigration remained consistent after the enactment of the quotas until the quotas were lifted in 1965.What is interesting after 1965 was that the primary country of immigration was no longer dominated by the Europeans, but rather by China, Canada, and Mexico. This is indicative of the shift in economic hardship that took place in the world of the past century. While Europe was stabilizing, Mexico and China began to falter. A major increase of North American immigration started to pick up during the 1990s during the commencement of Industrial Westernization, otherwise know as the process of moving factories form North America, to China. Mexico's economy collapse after this, and many sought better economic opportunity in the states.

name: Nicholas
comment info: I notice the period between 1850-1870 was when the largest amount of people in the US population was born abroad, at around 15%. I wonder why the percentage was at its peak then? It could be attributed to the fact that the US was still a relatively new country, and many perceived the U.S. to have lots of opportunities. I notice that in the earliest 50-ish that the graph depicts, a large chunk of the US population that was born abroad came from Ireland. I wonder if it was because of the potato famine at that time. I also notice that following a spike in immigration during the 1910s, Congress established immigration quotas that directly led to a significant decrease in the share of the US population that was born abroad. I noticed that after Congress rolled back the immigration quotas, there was a drop in the US population that was born in Europe, and an increase in immigration from the Americas and Asia. I wonder what led Congress to enact and eventually revoke their immigration quotas; what kind of measures were they looking at that influenced their decision? I see that starting around the 2000s, there were more immigrants from the Middle East and Africa when prior to that time period they weren’t even visible on the graph. I wonder what caused more immigration from these areas. I wonder what this graph will look like in the coming years--what regions or countries will become more prominent on the graph, and will there be a new peak percentage of the population born abroad?

name: Angelo Valleriani
comment info:
The main purpose of this graph it to suggest that creating immigration quotas works in controlling the flow of immigrants. Though, this plot hides the percentage of illegal immigrants.

A few comments about what happens after 1968.

I don't think that we can reach conclusions about the mechanisms of the changes without looking at the absolute numbers that make the percentages. A change in the percentage can be due to increase/decrease of the immigration rate and/or to a decrease/increase of the native population (e.g. due to changes in the birth rate). 

If we had to assume that the US native population is constant over time (i.e. population growth is due only to immigrants, at least in the post WW2 time), and in the context of growing world population (doubled in the last 50 years) we see that Europe (no population growth) has an apparent decrease in the share of immigrants compared to other regions (e.g. Asia and Africa) whose population is growing rapidly. This may indicate that the change in immigration pressure is simply due to changes in demographic pressure. 

We may also attribute the growth in the share of immigrants from the Americas as due to the bad economic conditions in most of the latin-american countries after 1990.

name: Metropolitan Montessori Middle School
comment info:
1a) We noticed that there was a very large population born in Europe up until the 1960s, and then it shifted to a large population born in Americas and Asia. 

1b) We also noticed that there was a lag after the Congress rolls back quotas before an uptake in population that was born abroad.

2a) We wondered if the new generations born in the United States will be represented by the "white" part of the graph, meaning that there are two sides to this graph.

2b) We also wondered what causes people to move to the United States? Was it because of historical events? Does it have to do with stability, rights, religious freedom, or to get a better life such as education or housing?

2c) We wondered the lag in uptake after 1965 had to do with recovery from country-based immigration quotas.

3) We feel connected to this graph because we are all represented: someone from our family moved to the United States at one point or another.

4) We would like to name the graph "The Shifting Plates of Immigration"

name: I.B.
comment info:
I notice that pre-1921, the major groups of foreign-born immigrants were from Canada, Ireland, and Germany. In contrast, post-1965, the majority were either from Mexico or Asian countries. I also notice that there were very few Latin American, African, Asian, or Middle Eastern up until 1965. Clearly, rolling back these immigration quotas increased the country's diversity, but why was it so white-dominated pre-1921? 
I have family who have gone through (and are still attempting to get through) the immigration process. I don't know whether or not these statistics reflect anything positive about America so much as they have opened up new avenues of oppression for immigrants, such as cages for Mexican children.
